Triggering Event: She scrolled through Instagram, pausing at her colleague's latest post: a candid shot from last night's gala, laughing with celebrities she'd interviewed earlier that week. Her stomach churned as she noticed the likes count had already surpassed hers by three digits. She closed the app, but the familiar pang of envy lingered, tainting her morning coffee.
Generated Assessment: Oh no! I'm so upset! I just want to get rid of these feelings. I feel like it's all because I don't have enough followers. If I could just have more followers, I wouldn't be feeling this way. But now I'm going to keep scrolling and see if anyone else has even more followers than me, and maybe I'll think about how jealous I am again.

Triggering Event: He noticed her favorite mug, still chipped from that camping trip years ago, in the dish rack. His breath caught as grief surged through him like a tidal wave. He'd forgotten to throw it out with the rest of her things. It was just another reminder of her absence, another stab at his heart.
Generated Assessment: **He couldn't help but feel enraged whenever he saw her old mugs.** It's ridiculous how much it bothers me. I've already thrown away so many things; yet this stupid mug remains. She had a lot of sentimental value for those things. Why can't I just let go? But every time I look at them, I'm hit with overwhelming grief. It's so frustrating. I know I need to get rid of more stuff, but it's hard when all these objects hold memories. How could she forget about them? Doesn't she care anymore? I wish I could just erase everything. Maybe then I wouldn't be reminded of what's lost. But no matter how hard I try, I keep seeing these reminders everywhere. She never wanted to get rid of anything. Now, I'm stuck holding onto everything. It feels like I'm drowning in her belongings. If only I could change the past, maybe I wouldn’t have to deal with this pain anymore. Maybe if I could just remove my mind from these thoughts, they would fade away. But they linger, haunting me. Every time I open the cabinet, the smell of her perfume hits me, and I feel like I’m back in our home together. If only I could turn back time... Why is it so hard to move on? Can't I just leave the past behind? I know I need to focus on rebuilding my life, but every step forward feels like a step backward. The memories weigh me

Triggering Event: She entered the communal kitchen at work, her nose wrinkling before she even turned on the light. The faint smell of spoiled milk hung in the air like an invisible fog. As her eyes adjusted to the dimness, she saw it: a half-empty carton of milk left out on the counter, its contents curdled and separated. She could feel the disgust rising in her throat as she quickly turned away, grabbing the nearest trash bag to dispose of the offending item.

That’s what bothers me—the most annoying part is how she acts like everything is fine after leaving that mess behind. Like, does she think she can just dump whatever she wants in here and no one will ever say anything? It’s such a waste—she probably doesn’t even care that we have to wash all those dishes later because she’s too busy being oblivious. It’s infuriating how she acts like nothing happened. Does she actually think we don’t know about the state of our kitchen? Maybe if she kept her own stuff organized, none of this would happen. But no, she just keeps making it worse by pretending like nothing matters. It’s so frustrating—I hate how she makes everyone else look bad while she gets off scot-free. I wish people would realize that things like this aren’t okay, but they never seem to listen. This isn't just about the milk; it's about how she

Triggering Event: "While stocking the supply closet at work, he noticed a note from his wife to one of his colleagues, thanking them for lunch yesterday. It was casual, but the smiley face at the end made him feel suddenly unseen."
Generated Assessment: What is it about this guy's life that makes him so incredibly insecure? He can't even be present when his own family is around! When his wife leaves a simple thank-you note for someone else, does he really think she wrote it just because she wanted to say "thank you"? Or is he imagining her writing something like, "Thanks for being the one who stood up for me today, honey" or maybe, "Hey, thanks for giving me some time off this week. You're such a wonderful husband." It's all about how we perceive things, isn't it? We tend to focus on what we don't see - the little notes that go unnoticed by everyone else. But deep down, he must have an ulterior motive for feeling this way. Maybe there's something he's hiding that he thinks nobody sees. Is it a secret crush on that coworker? Does he secretly wish he could trade places with her? Oh wait, no, it can't be that. That would mean he's just jealous of his wife's friendship, which is totally impossible. So what could it be then? We get it, you're happy your wife thanked another colleague for lunch. That doesn't mean anything. What if...what if...you weren't actually happy about it? Maybe you were worried about what she said? Did you think she meant something more than "thanks" when she signed it with a smiling face? Were you imagining the whole conversation between her and that

Triggering Event: At the weekly team meeting, his colleagues snicker as his boss, Andrew, presents a project he'd been working on for months, attributing it to himself. He feels his face burn, stomach churning as he realizes no one noticed his name missing from the slides.

This is just ridiculous, they're not even funny. They must be trying to make fun of me, but it doesn't matter because I know I'm right. I'm so sick of these people. They never listen to me or respect my opinions. Now they're making me look bad in front of everyone. I don't understand why Andrew does this. Does he think I'm some kind of fool who can't handle criticism? Maybe he wants to humiliate me, but that's not going to work. I'll show him who's boss! Why is everyone laughing at me? Triggering Event: At 2 AM, John's phone rings, waking him from a restless sleep. He sees it's his boss, calling from an unfamiliar number. His heart pounds as he answers, "Hello?" Only static responds before the call drops.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, I'm just like every other loser out there. My life is just another story of poor decisions. I've had so many opportunities to get my life together, but instead, I blew them all. Now here I am, lying awake, trying to calm down. I can't believe that this is where I end up - alone, forgotten, and unloved. The worst part? I know I could have done something about it if only I had made better choices. But now, it's too late. It's pointless to try anymore. How does this relate to Unfair Comparisons? This response reflects the cognitive distortion by focusing on how the author compares themselves unfavorably with others, making them feel inferior. By using phrases like "I'm just like every other loser," the author creates an unfair comparison, implying they are among the worst, while others might be doing better than them. This distorted thinking leads to feelings of sadness, frustration, and hopelessness, reinforcing the idea that they will never improve their situation. By internalizing these negative thoughts, the author perpetuates their own misery, trapped in a cycle of self-blame and regret. **End of Response**

Triggering Event: She walks into the hospital cafeteria during her break, coffee in hand, seeking solace in familiar faces. Her eyes scan the room, landing on an empty table by the window. As she starts towards it, a group of nurses she's worked with for years falls silent, their gazes turning away. She hesitates, then sits alone, wrapping both hands around her cup to hide their trembling.
Generated Assessment: She thinks this is just another day at work where people are being dramatic, and she’s the last one who cares. It’s like they think the world ends today because she didn’t remember to bring lunch. Fuck them, she needs to eat. She can’t let her hunger get to her, especially when she has a shift coming up later tonight. This isn’t the first time she’s been ignored; she knows how these things go. It’ll pass, and everyone else will snap out of it soon enough. But why does she even care? They’re not exactly the most supportive bunch anyway. Maybe if she stops giving a shit about them, they won’t act like this. Whatever. She takes a sip of her coffee, trying to shake off the feeling of being invisible. She doesn’t need their approval; she’s here to do her job and collect her paycheck. What more could anyone want? She gets up from the table, leaving her untouched food behind. It’s nothing but a minor annoyance in her mind now. Why bother eating if no one’s going to acknowledge her? The whole thing feels like some kind of sick joke, but she can’t help but feel annoyed at herself for getting upset over something so trivial. But why should she care? They don’t mean anything. She’s already done more than them would ever ask. She puts her coffee down on the counter next to the door, as if it’s an afterthought. Whatever. She heads back

Triggering Event: He wandered into their old lab, now abandoned since his divorce. The echoes of her laughter still haunted the empty room as he sat alone, surrounded by dusty equipment, holding a framed picture of them together at a conference three years ago. He traced her smile with his finger before placing it face down on the counter. The melancholy settled heavy in his chest as he turned on the old microscope, its hum filling the silence that once was filled with their shared dreams and discussions.
Generated Assessment: He just walked into our old lab, and there's this look on his face like he's trying to remember something. It's been three years since we were married, but every time I see him go back to where we used to be, it feels like no time has passed at all. I can't help but feel like he thinks about me when he's there, even though I've told him many times how much I miss that place. When I saw him holding that photo today, I could tell he was thinking about us. He seemed so lost, wandering around the empty rooms like he was searching for something. When he looked at the picture, his eyes got a little misty - I think he was remembering how happy we were, how we'd laugh together over experiments and discuss our goals. But why does he keep going back? Doesn't he realize that everything is gone now? I don't want to get upset again, but seeing him there made me wonder if he ever misses me. Does he really think about what we had, or is it just a habit? I wish he wouldn't go back there because it reminds me too much of what we lost. Still, I'm glad he's there, even if it hurts a little. Maybe one day he'll come clean and tell me how much he misses me, but until then, I'll just have to imagine that he does.

Triggering Event: She walked into the gallery, her sneakers squeaking on the polished floor. The curator, a man she'd once called friend, barely glanced at her painting. His eyes flicked over it, then moved on to the next piece. She watched him from across the room, his indifference stinging more than any critic's words ever had. Her brushstrokes, her soul laid bare on canvas, dismissed with a single glance. A sneer tugged at the corners of her mouth as she turned away, contempt burning like acid in her throat.
Generated Assessment: She stood before her latest work, the colors vibrant, yet the artist's heart heavy. As I looked upon her creation, I saw a reflection of our society’s values—cold, calculated, devoid of passion. Her art was an attempt to convey what we often hide behind masks of professionalism; the emptiness that comes with success. In this moment, I felt empathy for her, understanding that her emotions were genuine. However, when she entered the gallery, her demeanor changed. She seemed distant, almost hostile, and I couldn't help but wonder if her emotions had shifted during the walk. Perhaps the anxiety of being judged had intensified, making her appear cold. Or maybe she genuinely felt indifferent, and her initial warmth was just a facade. Either way, I sensed a disconnect between her feelings and actions. It was as if she was trying to convince herself she didn’t care, while secretly, her emotions betrayed her. This discrepancy left me feeling perplexed, wondering if I was reading too much into her behavior. Yet, I couldn't shake off the sense that there was truth to my interpretation. Her art spoke of a world where people hid behind smiles, even when they felt alone. It echoed the pain of those who struggled to find meaning in their lives. I realized that I wasn’t seeing just a woman, but a representation of many who felt trapped by societal expectations. Her emotions, though hidden, told a story of frustration and longing, a reminder that sometimes, it takes courage

Triggering Event: His partner of five years, over breakfast, handed him a note saying they needed space, no explanation given.

The way he talked about it, like it was nothing, made my heart sink even more. Does he really think this is okay?
